unit: Unit 4 | Probability, Random Variables, and Probability Distributions
title: Steroid Usage
question_text:
Many collegiate athletes are tested for performance-enhancing steroids.
Suppose a standard test gives a positive result for the usage of steroids $98\%$ of the time on individuals who use steroids. However, the drug test shows a positive result for steroids when the individual is in fact not using steroids, $8\%$ of the time.
If $15\%$ of college athletes use steroids, what is the probability that a randomly selected test result gives a positive test for steroids?

$$(0.15 \cdot 0.98)+(0.85 \cdot 0.08) = 0.215$$

Thus, the correct answer is Choice 'D'.

Alternatively, one could use a tree diagram for this problem. A tree diagram is useful in that it conveniently displays all possible outcomes for college athletes in this context.

When making a tree diagram, the base of the tree diagram is the non-conditional probabilities. In this situation, the base of the tree diagram is whether the individual uses steroids or not. The branches of the tree diagram are the non-conditional probabilities. In this situation, the branches of the tree diagram represent what the test result shows given one uses steroids, and given one does not use steroids.
